Award.AwardTitle: Recovery of high frequency wave fields, kinetic theory of photons and entropy satisfying methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project develops mathematical tools and numerical algorithms to study multiscale problems governed by a selected set of partial differential equations arising in diverse applications. The proposed work consists of three projects: recovery of high frequency wave fields governed by a variety of wave equations, including hyperbolic equations such as the acoustic wave equation, dispersive equations such as the Schroedinger equation, and the time independent Helmholtz equation; development of kinetic theory of photons in the transport of energy; and design of entropy satisfying discontinuous Galerkin methods for kinetic Fokker-Planck equations, with emphasis on kinetic models arising in polymeric fluids and collective motions in biology.

Each of the proposed projects has the potential to have a significant impact on problems that are both fundamental and technologically important. Recovery of high frequency wave fields is a fundamental problem in high frequency wave propagation, the study of which can provide a deeper understanding of high frequency wave dynamics occurring in various applications. The study of condensation of photons would result in methods which may potentially be suitable for designing novel light sources. Entropy satisfying methods are important in capturing the right physics in long time numerical simulations. The design of such methods has the potential to elucidate many aspects of the physical process. The theory will be applied to and driven by identified practical applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many physical problems have multiple temporal and spatial scales that pose tremendous difficulties for mathematical analysis, and modeling as well as numerical simulation, and the governing mathematical models are often in the form of partial differential equations (PDEs). The main function of a time-dependent PDE is, given some initial data, to allow us to compute the solution and use it for prediction of  future behavior. Therefore, the fundamental question one can ask about a PDE is evolutionary behavior of solutions,  including oscillation, concentration, or singularity formation in PDE solutions. The knowledge obtained may be further used to guide the design of efficient algorithms which can capture the rich physical phenomena. The main objective of our research investigation was to develop mathematical tools and numerical algorithms through the study of  several  important PDEs.

The project led to main advances in the asymptotic approximation of high frequency waves and how to use Gaussian beams to recover oscillatory wave fields.  Recovery of high frequency wave fields is a fundamental problem in computational high frequency wave propagation, our study provided a deeper understanding of high frequency wave dynamics occurring in applications. Our recovery theory applies to a set of Partial differential equations, including hyperbolic equations such as the acoustic wave equation, dispersive equations such as the Schrodinger equation, and the time independent Helmholtz equation.  A new mechanism using non-squeezing techniques has been discovered and analyzed. This knowledge has been essentially used to prove optimal recovery rates for Gaussian beam superpositions.  The recovery relies on the optimal error control of the Gaussian beam solutions in terms of the frequency parameter, and applicable to general settings regardless of number of caustics and the space dimensions. The developed theory then gives a rigorous foundation for beam based numerical methods used to solve wave equations in the high frequency regime.

Another direction of the project focused on the development of kinetic theory of photons through the study  of the Kompaneets equation.  This equation describes a field of photons exchanging energy by Compton  scattering with the free electrons of a homogeneous, isotropic, nonrelativistic, thermal plasma. The project  advanced our understanding of how the Kompaneets equation generally describes the process of relaxation to  equilibrium over large time and how it captures the phenomenon of Bose–Einstein condensation in particular.
For the model equation we proved existence and uniqueness theorems for global weak solutions. In some cases a  Bose–Einstein condensate will form in finite time, and we show that it will continue to gain photons forever  afterward. Moreover we showed that every solution approaches a stationary solution for large time.

The third research direction of the project was to design, analyze and test entropy satisfying high order numerical methods for kinetic Fokker-Planck equations, with emphasis on kinetic models arising in Polymeric fluids, also on equations modeling various crowded motions, such as the cell motion, the ion transport, and the wave scattering.  Entropy satisfying methods are important in numerically capturing the right physics in long time simulation. The project led to deeper understanding of how to incorporate the underlying physics into high order numerical methods to solve underlying PDE models, so that the obtained numerical algorithms are able to preserve the intrinsic solution structure, predict time dynamics, and capture the rich phenomena at physically relevant scales. These algorithms will also have potential applications in important emerging areas of  complex fluids and active matter.
